Invent new coinages in each stanza and introduce a named creature. Add onomatopoeia and some alliteration. Arc: warning → preparation → encounter/slay → return/celebration. Echo the opening at the end. Avoid verbatim lines; limit canonical words.
poem:
The Murkralf Underloom

Underpass glimmer-loom, where neon drips and shadows loom,  
Clack, click—city clack,  
Echoes curl a crouched-up cry: they whisper Murkralf in the gloom,  
Hush—hiss—hardened clack.  

We sharpen brimblade bright with flint-fret spit and ember-flare,  
Whish—snap—sing,  
Pip straps scrimble-haft and tangle-helm; our shoulders square to flare,  
Step—stomp—ready sing.  

Sudden—shoom—the Murkralf uprears, its gorglefang aglow with bane,  
Crash—thud—thwack—crack,  
We bore the brimblade through grizzle-hide and growl, the tunnel took its bane,  
Shreek—smack—crack.  

Homeward our lanterns toss the dark, a jubelchord of warm-bright bloom,  
Ha—ho—hurrah ring,  
Coins and gladwheep clatter, laughter peals; the arch exhales a softened bloom,  
Underpass glimmer-gleam once more—footfall ring.
label: high

poem:
Murmur-Mist at Morn

When morn-murmur wrapped the wheat in wool of white,  
pssh! piped the panes along the silent lane;  
A tinny tongued town-cry told of dim and dreadful night,  
“Mark well the blur that skulks with fogfiend’s bane.”  

Sages and smiths strapped belts — a bristlewit brigade,  
Clack! went the iron rod;  
Gran spat a sloam to soothe the sapling's stubborn shade,  
“Stoke up!” the bell-brow bellowed, clutch the keeper’s rod.  

They tracked the tangle-trails where filmy wavelets low,  
whump! rang the snare and snap;  
And there the Mire-Morrgaw — mole-eyed, misty-moan — did show,  
Slice—snick—went froth and fang, it blapped and fell with slap.  

They hauled the hush to hearths and hung a silver song,  
Hush! piped the town, soft—fell the white;  
Gran’s sloam and brum made bonfire-bread and laughter long,  
And every voice gave thanks — the dawn unrolled the white.
label: high

poem:
Glim and Gloam: A Twice-Trod Tale

Glim and gloam, the dusk-bell blew, (A)
Hark, Grindlewomp—shree! its teeth go clang; (B)
Tread not the thrumfill lane if heart be not true, (A)
Whump—whiff—night-needles bristle, clang! (B)

We braid bramble-bands, glass and grit made keen, (A)
Clack—sparrowsteel sings up a steady tone; (B)
Kin kiss the coin, pom-dirks bright as brim and wide, (C)
Hush—brim-bells answer, echoing our tone. (B)

From fern-fret vale the Grindlewomp did gleam, (A)
Hiss—whump—its hoard-glob burst with doom; (B)
I heaved the bray-blade, flash and fierce with gleam, (A)
Clang—thud—its fangful fall sank soft to doom. (B)

We wend with wattle-wares, laughter's nets untorn, (A)
Tra-la—mirthmote bells go clear to home; (B)
Ale-foam and song-swill set the lane alight, (C)
Huzz—clap—glim and gloam—the dusk-bell hums us home. (B)
label: high

poem:
The Bramble-Track Ballad

Mind the bramble-track of slyling sway, (A)
shh—hear the whish of wakefall grass; (B)
do not drift the fey-foot, nor stray the way, (A)
for knitter-glow will knot the wandering pass. (B)

Grip your glint-knife, gumpled for surprise; (A)
whish—pack the pelt and polish the bone-stone, (B)
tuck true tales into the wildroot's eyes; (C)
clack and clench—let courage count the bone-stone. (B)

Then leapt the Brimbeast—Skelth, a thornbright bane, (A)
thud! clang!—its gore-groan split the midnight seam; (B)
you slammed with sail-sword, sang the silver-stained mane, (A)
crunch—clack—its bellies broke, and broke the seam. (B)

Home with hymn-hops and harvest-hum we roam, (A)
clink—cheer—pennons prance on post and grass, (B)
we tell of gumpled guile and Skelth undone, (C)
and hush—tread the bramble-track where slyling sway meets grass. (B)
label: high

poem:
The Conference-Clang

Beware the meetwisp in the conference room,  
It clanks—clankle!—a hollow ring,  
Where swivel-shadows bloom and swivel-lamps loom,  
Paper snicks, secret shushers softly sing.

We don cuff-jackets, brace the board—our charts go stark,  
Click-click—punctuate, point and state,  
With briefcase-saber, slideglass spear, we mark the arc,  
Thrum—attune, consolidate.

Then from the swivel-shelf sprang Glowerfang, gristlefang,  
It snorfed and smorked—snick!—then crash,  
We hurled the pointerlance; it bellowed—buck and clang,  
Whump! a final thwack; the beast went ash.

Back at the round walnut, mugs aloft, our couth-count cheer,  
Clip-clap—stap-stamp—ticker boom,  
We pin a Post-it pennant to the whiteboard—proud and clear,  
Sing hail, salute the meetwisp in the conference room.
label: high
